natural problem: Carson flips over the cards of a standard 52-card deck one at a time. What is the probability that he flips over the ace of spades before any face card (jack, queen or king)?
natural solution: There are 12 face cards, three from each suit. Within the deck, the 13 relevant cards (the face cards and the ace of spades) are arranged in some order. The probability that the first of these 13 cards is the ace is therefore $\boxed{\frac{1}{13}}$.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes ace_of_spades face_cards total_cards :: real
assumes h0 : "ace_of_spades = 1"
and h1 : "face_cards = 12"
and h2 : "total_cards = 52"
shows  "Prob (ace_of_spades_before_face_cards) = 1 / 13"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Carson flips over the cards of a standard 52-card deck one at a time. What is the probability that he flips over the ace of spades before any face card (jack, queen or king)? The final Answer is \frac{1}{13}
 ### Proof
 There are 12 face cards, three from each suit. Within the deck, the 13 relevant cards (the face cards and the ace of spades) are arranged in some order. The probability that the first of these 13 cards is the ace is therefore $\boxed{\frac{1}{13}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes ace_of_spades face_cards total_cards :: real
assumes h0 : "ace_of_spades = 1"
and h1 : "face_cards = 12"
and h2 : "total_cards = 52"
shows  "Prob (ace_of_spades_before_face_cards) = 1 / 13"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: What is the probability of drawing an Ace of Spades before any face card from a standard 52-card deck? The final answer is $\frac{1}{13}$.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes prob :: real
assumes h0 : "prob = (\<Sum> i \<in> {1..13}. (1/52) * (1/(51 - 4 * (i - 1))))"
shows  "prob = 1 / 13"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Carson flips over the cards of a standard 52-card deck one at a time. What is the probability that he flips over the ace of spades before any face card (jack, queen or king)? The final Answer is \frac{1}{13}
 ### Proof
 There are 12 face cards, three from each suit. Within the deck, the 13 relevant cards (the face cards and the ace of spades) are arranged in some order. The probability that the first of these 13 cards is the ace is therefore $\boxed{\frac{1}{13}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes prob :: real
assumes h0 : "prob = (\<Sum> i \<in> {1..13}. (1/52) * (1/(51 - 4 * (i - 1))))"
shows  "prob = 1 / 13"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: Find the probability of drawing an Ace from a standard deck of 52 cards, then a King from the remaining 51 cards, then a Queen from the remaining 48 cards, and so on, until the 13th card is a 2. The final answer is $\frac{1}{13}$.

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes total_cards face_cards :: nat
and ace_of_spades_probability :: real
assumes h0 : "total_cards = 52"
and h1 : "face_cards = 12"
and h2 : "ace_of_spades_probability = (total_cards - face_cards) / total_cards"
shows  "ace_of_spades_probability = 1 / 13"
a_2.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Carson flips over the cards of a standard 52-card deck one at a time. What is the probability that he flips over the ace of spades before any face card (jack, queen or king)? The final Answer is \frac{1}{13}
 ### Proof
 There are 12 face cards, three from each suit. Within the deck, the 13 relevant cards (the face cards and the ace of spades) are arranged in some order. The probability that the first of these 13 cards is the ace is therefore $\boxed{\frac{1}{13}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes total_cards face_cards :: nat
and ace_of_spades_probability :: real
assumes h0 : "total_cards = 52"
and h1 : "face_cards = 12"
and h2 : "ace_of_spades_probability = (total_cards - face_cards) / total_cards"
shows  "ace_of_spades_probability = 1 / 13"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem: A standard deck of 52 playing cards contains 12 face cards (kings, queens, and jacks). What is the probability of drawing the Ace of Spades from the remaining non-face cards? Express your answer as a fraction. The final answer is $\frac{1}{13}$.

a_3.formal problem:
theorem
fixes probability :: real
assumes h0 : "probability = (\<Sum>i\<in>{1..4} . card {j \<in> {1..52}. card_type j = face_card \<and> position j < position i})"
and h1 : "card_type 1 = ace_of_spades"
and h2 : "\<forall>i \<in> {2..52}. card_type i \<noteq> ace_of_spades"
and h3 : "face_cards = {j \<in> {1..52}. card_type j = jack \<or> card_type j = queen \<or> card_type j = king}"
shows  "probability = 1 / 13"
a_3.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Carson flips over the cards of a standard 52-card deck one at a time. What is the probability that he flips over the ace of spades before any face card (jack, queen or king)? The final Answer is \frac{1}{13}
 ### Proof
 There are 12 face cards, three from each suit. Within the deck, the 13 relevant cards (the face cards and the ace of spades) are arranged in some order. The probability that the first of these 13 cards is the ace is therefore $\boxed{\frac{1}{13}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes probability :: real
assumes h0 : "probability = (\<Sum>i\<in>{1..4} . card {j \<in> {1..52}. card_type j = face_card \<and> position j < position i})"
and h1 : "card_type 1 = ace_of_spades"
and h2 : "\<forall>i \<in> {2..52}. card_type i \<noteq> ace_of_spades"
and h3 : "face_cards = {j \<in> {1..52}. card_type j = jack \<or> card_type j = queen \<or> card_type j = king}"
shows  "probability = 1 / 13"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_3.informal problem: In a standard deck of 52 playing cards, what is the probability of drawing the Ace of Spades (card 1) before drawing any of the 12 face cards (Jacks, Queens, or Kings)? The final answer is $\frac{1}{13}$.

a_4.formal problem:
theorem
fixes probability :: real
assumes h0 : "probability = (\<lambda>cards. 1 / cards)"
shows  "probability 13 = 1 / 13"
a_4.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Carson flips over the cards of a standard 52-card deck one at a time. What is the probability that he flips over the ace of spades before any face card (jack, queen or king)? The final Answer is \frac{1}{13}
 ### Proof
 There are 12 face cards, three from each suit. Within the deck, the 13 relevant cards (the face cards and the ace of spades) are arranged in some order. The probability that the first of these 13 cards is the ace is therefore $\boxed{\frac{1}{13}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes probability :: real
assumes h0 : "probability = (\<lambda>cards. 1 / cards)"
shows  "probability 13 = 1 / 13"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_4.informal problem: What is the probability of drawing a specific card from a deck of 13 cards? The final answer is $\frac{1}{13}$.

a_5.formal problem:
theorem
fixes probability :: real
assumes h0 : "probability = card {ace_of_spades} / card {ace_of_spades, jack, queen, king}"
shows  "probability = 1 / 13"
a_5.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Carson flips over the cards of a standard 52-card deck one at a time. What is the probability that he flips over the ace of spades before any face card (jack, queen or king)? The final Answer is \frac{1}{13}
 ### Proof
 There are 12 face cards, three from each suit. Within the deck, the 13 relevant cards (the face cards and the ace of spades) are arranged in some order. The probability that the first of these 13 cards is the ace is therefore $\boxed{\frac{1}{13}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes probability :: real
assumes h0 : "probability = card {ace_of_spades} / card {ace_of_spades, jack, queen, king}"
shows  "probability = 1 / 13"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_5.informal problem: What is the probability of drawing the Ace of Spades from a set consisting of the Ace of Spades, Jack, Queen, and King? The final answer is $\frac{1}{13}$.

a_6.formal problem:
theorem
fixes p :: real
assumes h0 : "p = (\<Sum>k\<in>{0..9}. (1 / 52) * (3/51)^k)"
shows  "p = 1 / 13"
a_6.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Carson flips over the cards of a standard 52-card deck one at a time. What is the probability that he flips over the ace of spades before any face card (jack, queen or king)? The final Answer is \frac{1}{13}
 ### Proof
 There are 12 face cards, three from each suit. Within the deck, the 13 relevant cards (the face cards and the ace of spades) are arranged in some order. The probability that the first of these 13 cards is the ace is therefore $\boxed{\frac{1}{13}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes p :: real
assumes h0 : "p = (\<Sum>k\<in>{0..9}. (1 / 52) * (3/51)^k)"
shows  "p = 1 / 13"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_6.informal problem: Find the sum of the geometric series with 10 terms, where the first term is $\frac{1}{52}$ and the common ratio is $\frac{3}{51}$. The final answer is $\frac{1}{13}$.

a_7.formal problem:

fixes deck :: "nat"
assumes h0 : "deck = 52"
and h1 : "face_cards = 12"
and h2 : "ace_of_spades = 1"
shows  "probability_flipping_ace_of_spades_before_face_cards = 1 / 13"

 ### Proof
 There are 12 face cards, three from each suit. Within the deck, the 13 relevant cards (the face cards and the ace of spades) are arranged in some order. The probability that the first of these 13 cards is the ace is therefore $\boxed{\frac{1}{13}}$.

theorem
fixes deck :: "nat"

a_7.informal problem: What is the probability of flipping the Ace of Spades before flipping any of the 12 face cards in a standard 52-card deck? The final answer is $\frac{1}{13}$.

a_8.formal problem:
theorem
fixes probability :: real
assumes h0 : "probability = (card {ace_of_spades} / card {ace_of_spades, face_cards})"
shows  "probability = 1 / 13"
a_8.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Carson flips over the cards of a standard 52-card deck one at a time. What is the probability that he flips over the ace of spades before any face card (jack, queen or king)? The final Answer is \frac{1}{13}
 ### Proof
 There are 12 face cards, three from each suit. Within the deck, the 13 relevant cards (the face cards and the ace of spades) are arranged in some order. The probability that the first of these 13 cards is the ace is therefore $\boxed{\frac{1}{13}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes probability :: real
assumes h0 : "probability = (card {ace_of_spades} / card {ace_of_spades, face_cards})"
shows  "probability = 1 / 13"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_8.informal problem: What is the probability of drawing an Ace of Spades from a set containing the Ace of Spades and all the face cards (Kings, Queens, and Jacks) in a standard deck of cards? The final answer is $\frac{1}{13}$.

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes probability :: real
assumes h0 : "probability = (\<Sum>(n::nat) | n \<in> {0..8}. 1 / 13 * (12 / 51)^n * (1 - (12 / 51))^(51 - n))"
shows  "probability = 1 / 13"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Carson flips over the cards of a standard 52-card deck one at a time. What is the probability that he flips over the ace of spades before any face card (jack, queen or king)? The final Answer is \frac{1}{13}
 ### Proof
 There are 12 face cards, three from each suit. Within the deck, the 13 relevant cards (the face cards and the ace of spades) are arranged in some order. The probability that the first of these 13 cards is the ace is therefore $\boxed{\frac{1}{13}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes probability :: real
assumes h0 : "probability = (\<Sum>(n::nat) | n \<in> {0..8}. 1 / 13 * (12 / 51)^n * (1 - (12 / 51))^(51 - n))"
shows  "probability = 1 / 13"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: Find the probability given by the sum $\sum_{n=0}^{8} \frac{1}{13} \cdot \left(\frac{12}{51}\right)^n \cdot \left(1 - \frac{12}{51}\right)^{51-n}$. The final answer is $\frac{1}{13}$.
